impose.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if someone in authority imposes a rule, punishment, tax etc, they force people to accept it
impose.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The court can impose a fine.
The government imposed a ban on the sale of ivory.
impose.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to force someone to have the same ideas, beliefs etc as you
impose.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: parents who impose their own moral values on their children
impose.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to expect or ask someone to do something for you when this is not convenient for them
impose.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: We could ask to stay the night, but I donâ€™t want to impose on them.
impose.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to have a bad effect on something or someone and to cause problems for them
impose.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Military spending imposes a huge strain on the economy.
impose.translation[0].definitions[3].not: In everyday English, people usually say put a ban/tax/burden/strain on something rather than impose a ban/tax/burden/strain on something:
The government put a higher tax on cigarettes.
This puts a lot of strain on families.
impose.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to officially order that something should be forbidden, taxed etc
impose.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The city council can not impose a utility tax without voter approval.
The US Commerce Department threatened to impose a 15% fee on subsidized lumber flooding US markets.
